TopicTitle: Non-Kerbal Canon References Within the Game.

Articles.Content:
Gentleman and germs, I have found something which absolutely tickled me to death in total nerd-gasmic fashion. While reading the part descriptions, I noticed a little something something that I found quite interesting. If one reads the description for the Z-100 Rechargeable battery bank, one may notice a little easter egg. As any self-respecting Whovian will know, reversing the polarity of anything will certainly fix said anything.

So my question to all ye explosion masters, is what other canon references have you noticed throughout the Kerbal Universe?
Reversing polarity is a common sci-fi technique for solving mysterious problems with obfuscated gadgetry. I don't know if Dr. Who used it first or not, but I first heard it a lot on Star Trek.

You can find black monoliths scattered around the solar system, if I recall correctly. There's one on the Mun that I know of, and I've seen footage of one near Kerbal Space Center on Youtube, too, a reference to 2001: A Space Odyssey.
"What is this, an engine for ants?" is most certainly a reference to Zoolander.

You can find black monoliths scattered around the solar system, if I recall correctly. There's one on the Mun that I know of, and I've seen footage of one near Kerbal Space Center on Youtube, too, a reference to 2001: A Space Odyssey.

There is also the science report when orbiting Jool. I forget which one it is but has a 2001 reference as well.
There's also the rover on Duna, as well as the Kerbal face

There is also the science report when orbiting Jool. I forget which one it is but has a 2001 reference as well.

It's the materials study, "you try to open the doors but it keeps on saying "I can't do that." upon looking in the controls it opens though."
Mk2 Lander-can is manufactured by Sean's Cannery, a reference to a particular ex-British spy...
There is also the Armstrong memorial, and every time they write Rockomax, I read Roskosmos.
Don't forget the crashed UFO near the north pole.
The amount of 2001: Space Odyssey references in the science results around Jool is too darn high
When you transmit using the biggest Communotron, there are numbers written on the inside - one is the launch date for Sputnik 1, the other spells out 'beep' in hexadecimal.

The amount of 2001: Space Odyssey references in the science results around Jool is too darn high

So joyfully true ;D
